When Mom and Dad got divorced last year, he started sneaking into the abandoned school greenhouse at night, nursing forgotten seedlings back to life.

I followed him tonight because I was worried, not because I wanted to get him in trouble. But seeing him run from me like I'm some kind of threat breaks my heart. He thinks I'll ruin his secret garden, his one safe place where broken things can grow again.

I climb the fence after him, calling his name softly. Inside the greenhouse, hundreds of tiny plants reach toward makeshift grow lights powered by solar batteries. It's beautiful—a hidden world he's created from nothing.

"Jake," I whisper, finding him crouched behind a tomato plant. "This is incredible. Can you teach me?"

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. The temporal displacement device on my wrist beeps frantically—he's not from this timeline. Neither am I, technically, but I'm here on official business.

Agent 7742 has been jumping through decades, leaving ripples in the timestream that threaten to unravel reality itself. The Temporal Enforcement Bureau tracked him to this suburban park in 2024, but he's clever—using historical knowledge to stay one step ahead.

He stumbles near the playground, and I see the device strapped to his forearm sparking dangerously. Time jumpers always think they can outrun consequences, but paradoxes have a way of catching up. The grass around his feet begins to shimmer, showing glimpses of this place in different eras—a wheat field, a construction site, a parking lot.

"Stop!" I shout. "You're tearing holes in causality!"

He spins around, and I recognize his face from the wanted bulletins. But he's older now, scarred by years of running through time. "I'm trying to save her," he gasps. "My daughter. She dies tomorrow."

Sometimes the hardest part of this job is explaining that some futures can't be changed.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. But the figure is me—or rather, the me I used to be. The me who ran from everything: responsibility, relationships, the mirror's honest reflection.

I've been chasing my shadow-self through the labyrinth of my subconscious for what feels like hours. Each time I get close, he bolts, leaving behind fragments of memories I've tried to forget. The time I lied to Sarah about the affair. The job interview I sabotaged because success felt too dangerous. The phone calls from Dad I never answered.

Now he's cornered against the wall of my childhood home, the one that exists only in dreams. His face is mine but younger, unmarked by the weight of accumulated mistakes. He's everything I was before life taught me to compromise.

"You can't keep running," I tell him, my voice echoing in the dreamscape.

"Watch me," he replies, but his voice cracks with exhaustion.

I extend my hand. "It's time to come home."

For the first time, he stops running. Integration is painful, but necessary. Tomorrow, I'll wake up whole.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass."

responses.text: The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. I curse under my breath, knowing I'm losing precious seconds as he stumbles but recovers. Three weeks I've been tracking this bastard through the city's underbelly, following a trail of missing persons and cryptic symbols carved into abandoned buildings. My badge weighs heavy in my pocket—Detective Morrison would have my head if he knew I was here alone, chasing shadows in Riverside Park at dawn. But this is personal now. The figure ahead clutches something against his chest, probably another victim's belonging. His black hoodie billows as he sprints toward the treeline, and I can hear his labored breathing echoing in the morning mist. My radio crackles with static, but I ignore it. The grass beneath my boots is treacherous, each step threatening to send me sprawling, but I push harder. He's heading for the old maintenance shed—if he reaches it, he'll disappear into the tunnel system beneath the city. Not this time. I draw my weapon, shouting a warning that cuts through the silence like a blade.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. "Wait!" I call out, waving the wallet above my head. "You dropped this!" But Marcus is already halfway across the soccer field, his morning jog interrupted by what he clearly thinks is a mugging attempt. I can't blame him—I'm wearing all black workout gear, and in the pre-dawn gloom, I probably look like trouble. His arms pump frantically as he navigates around the sprinkler puddles, occasionally glancing back with wide, terrified eyes. This is exactly why Mom told me to wear bright colors when exercising alone. I slow to a walk, realizing the chase is futile. His wallet had fallen out of his pocket near the park bench where I'd been stretching, but now he's probably calling 911 from behind the safety of the pavilion. I set the wallet on the bench with a note: "Found this during my run. Hope you got some good cardio! - Your friendly neighborhood 'mugger'." Tomorrow, I'm definitely wearing neon pink. Maybe then good Samaritans won't flee in terror when I try to return their belongings.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. Of course he runs. They always run when they realize what I am. The morning mist clings to my ethereal form as I glide after him, my feet barely touching the ground. He's fast for a mortal, but fear makes him clumsy. I watch him stumble, recover, stumble again. The scent of his terror is intoxicating—metallic and sharp, like copper pennies dissolved in rainwater. He stole from the old cemetery last night, disturbing graves that should have remained untouched. The ancient locket now burns against his chest, its chain leaving blistered marks on his throat. He doesn't understand that some treasures carry curses older than the city itself. His breath comes in ragged gasps as he reaches the iron fence, fingers scrambling for purchase on the wet metal. But iron cannot stop me. Nothing can. I materialize before him, my hollow eyes reflecting his final moments of understanding. "You took something that wasn't yours," I whisper, my voice like autumn leaves scraping against tombstones. He opens his mouth to scream, but only silence emerges. The locket falls to the grass, finally returning home.

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. "Jamie, wait up!" I shout, but my little brother is already disappearing behind the oak trees. He's been avoiding me for weeks, ever since Mom and Dad's divorce papers were finalized. I know he blames me for not fighting harder to keep them together, for choosing Dad's side when lawyers started asking questions. The morning air is crisp against my face as I follow his familiar path—the same route we used to take to our secret fort when we were kids. His dark hoodie, the one I gave him for his thirteenth birthday, catches on a low branch. He's always been faster than me, but grief has made him desperate. I find him eventually, curled up in the hollow of our old climbing tree, tears streaming down his face. "I thought you hated me too," he whispers when I sit beside him. "I thought everyone was leaving." I pull him close, remembering when he used to fit perfectly under my arm. "Never," I promise, meaning it. "Brothers don't abandon each other, even when the whole world falls apart."

The dark figure starts running when he sees me coming, his sneakers slipping on the dew-slicked grass. Subject 47 is faster than the others, but the neural implant in his skull still glows faintly through his hood—a dead giveaway in the pre-dawn darkness. My enhanced vision tracks his heat signature as he weaves between the synthetic trees of Sector 7's recreation zone. The Corporation's morning patrol won't begin for another hour, giving us a narrow window for extraction. "Phoenix to Base," I whisper into my comm unit. "Target acquired. Initiating retrieval protocol." He's heading for the maintenance tunnels beneath the artificial lake, probably hoping to lose me in the labyrinth of pipes and cables that keep this dome city functioning. Smart, but not smart enough. My cybernetic legs propel me forward with inhuman speed, closing the distance despite the treacherous terrain. He stumbles again, and I see the fear in his eyes when he realizes I'm not Corporation security. "I'm here to help," I call out, showing him the resistance symbol tattooed on my palm. "Your memories are returning, aren't they? The ones they tried to erase?" He stops running, recognition flickering across his face. "Sarah?" he whispers. "You're supposed to be dead."

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Maya watched her younger brother Simon through the kitchen window as he sat alone on the swing set, his shoulders hunched against more than just the autumn chill. The divorce had hit him hardest—at eight, he didn't understand why Daddy couldn't just come home. She'd found the crayon drawing under his bed: stick figures of their family, but with Daddy's face scribbled out in angry black marks.

She tied her apron tighter and pulled the chocolate chip cookies from the oven. Simon's favorites. Tomorrow, she'd take him to the arcade after school, even though her college fund was already stretched thin from covering groceries. Next weekend, maybe they'd build that treehouse he'd been sketching obsessively.

Mom worked double shifts now, coming home exhausted and hollow-eyed. Someone had to fill the gaps, to notice when Simon forgot his lunch or when nightmares kept him awake. At nineteen, Maya had planned to move out, start her own life. But watching Simon's small frame on that swing, she knew those plans could wait.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon's life a happier one. Even if it meant putting her dreams on hold, even if it meant becoming the parent their parents couldn't be.

Elara's fingertips glowed silver as she touched the wilted roses in Simon's garden. The flowers straightened, petals unfurling in impossible shades of blue and gold—colors that existed only in the realm between dreams and waking. Simon wouldn't notice the magic, of course. Humans rarely did.

She'd been watching him for weeks now, this lonely old man who talked to his deceased wife's photograph each morning over cold coffee. The grief clung to him like morning fog, thick and suffocating. As a Guardian of Small Joys, Elara specialized in these cases—the forgotten ones who'd lost their spark.

She adjusted reality in tiny increments: his newspaper would arrive early with unexpectedly good news, the stray cat would finally trust him enough to accept food, his estranged daughter would find his old letters and remember why she loved him. Magic worked best in whispers, not shouts.

Tonight, she'd visit his dreams, weaving in memories of his late wife's laughter, the sound of children playing in distant summers. She couldn't bring back the dead or erase decades of loneliness. But she could remind him that wonder still existed in small moments.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon's life a happier one, one impossible flower at a time.

Dr. Chen adjusted the neural interface headset, her fingers trembling slightly as she initiated the connection to Simon's consciousness. The Memory Recovery Ward hummed with quiet efficiency, machines monitoring the comatose patients who'd volunteered for the experimental program.

Simon had been trapped in his own mind for three years following the hover-car accident. His family visited less frequently now, hope fading with each failed attempt to wake him. But Chen had discovered something remarkable in his brain scans—active dream sequences, elaborate fantasy worlds where he seemed... happy.

She dove deeper into his neural pathways, navigating through corridors of memory and imagination. There—a sunlit meadow where Simon played violin for an audience of woodland creatures, his face radiant with joy she'd never seen in his waking life. In this realm, he was confident, beloved, free from the anxiety that had plagued his conscious existence.

Chen began carefully reinforcing these positive neural patterns, strengthening the connections that sparked joy while gently dissolving the trauma that kept him locked away. It was delicate work—too much intervention could shatter his psyche entirely.

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon's life a happier one, even if that life existed only in the electric dreams of a sleeping mind.

The year was 1943, and rationing had made sugar scarce as gold, but Agnes saved every precious crystal for Simon's weekly visit. The ten-year-old evacuee from London had arrived at her Yorkshire cottage six months ago, all sharp elbows and suspicious eyes, clutching a battered suitcase and a photograph of parents he might never see again.

She'd watched him flinch at every loud noise, seen him hoard bread crusts under his mattress, noticed how he startled when she moved too quickly. The Blitz had stolen more than his home—it had stolen his childhood sense of safety.

But slowly, patiently, Agnes chipped away at his walls. She taught him to milk the goats, let him name the chickens ridiculous names like Sir Featherworth and Lady Cluckington. When nightmares woke him screaming, she'd sit by his bed humming old folk songs until dawn.

Today, she'd heard him laugh—actually laugh—when the rooster chased the postman up the garden path. It was the first genuine joy she'd witnessed from the boy.

The war raged on, letters from his parents grew infrequent, but here in this small pocket of peace, Agnes would do what she could to make Simon's life a happier one, one small kindness at a time.

Dr. Sarah Winters closed Simon's file and rubbed her tired eyes. Fifteen sessions, and still he sat in her office like a statue, answering in monosyllables, his gaze fixed somewhere beyond her diplomas on the wall. The court-mandated therapy following his suicide attempt wasn't working—at least, not in any measurable way.

But she'd noticed things. How his fingers tapped complex rhythms on his knee when he thought she wasn't looking. The way his eyes lit up, just briefly, when she'd mentioned her rescue dog last week. The sketch of a guitar half-hidden in his notebook margins.

Sarah made a decision that would probably violate several professional boundaries. Next session, she'd bring her guitar. Maybe they wouldn't talk at all—maybe they'd just play. She'd learned long ago that healing rarely followed textbook timelines.

She thought about Simon's mother in the waiting room, wringing her hands, asking the same desperate question: "Is he getting better?" How do you quantify hope? How do you measure the distance between existing and living?

For now, she would do what she could to make Simon's life a happier one, even if happiness came in frequencies too subtle for insurance forms to capture.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Elena watched Simon through the coffee shop window, his shoulders hunched over his laptop as he worked late into another evening. Three months since the divorce, and he still carried that hollow look in his eyes. She'd been his neighbor for two years, exchanging polite nods and weather commentary, but lately something stirred in her chest when she saw his pain.

She started small. A plate of homemade cookies left by his door with a note signed 'A friend.' Fresh flowers planted in the neglected garden bed outside his apartment. When his ancient car broke down, she anonymously paid for the repairs, telling the mechanic it was a gift from 'someone who cares.'

Simon began to smile again—tentative at first, then genuine. He started tending the flowers, even adding his own. Elena would catch glimpses of him humming while watering them. One evening, he knocked on her door holding a cup of coffee and wearing the first real smile she'd seen in months.

'I don't know who's been looking out for me,' he said, 'but I wanted to share this with someone. Would you like to sit on the porch and watch the sunset?'

Elena's heart swelled as she accepted the cup, knowing her secret acts of kindness had bloomed into something beautiful.

The memory charm was delicate work, requiring precision Maya had spent decades perfecting. She couldn't erase Simon's trauma entirely—that would leave dangerous gaps—but she could soften the sharp edges, blur the most painful moments until they felt like distant storms rather than daily hurricanes.

Simon had been her charge for six months now, assigned by the Council after his breakdown. A brilliant scientist whose mind had fractured under the weight of discovering his life's work had been used for destruction. The guilt was eating him alive, one sleepless night at a time.

Maya worked in whispers and shadows, weaving gentle dreams where his research saved lives instead of ending them. She planted seeds of hope in his subconscious: memories of thank-you letters from families, images of children playing in parks his inventions had protected. Not lies, exactly, but possibilities—alternate truths his mind could embrace.

Slowly, Simon began to sleep through the night. He returned to his laboratory, but this time with renewed purpose, developing medical applications for his technology. Maya watched from the ethereal plane as he laughed with colleagues, as color returned to his cheeks.

The Council would reassign her soon, but for now, she was content knowing she'd given Simon back his future.

Twelve-year-old Lucy had always been wise beyond her years, but watching her father Simon struggle after Mom's death had aged her further. He tried to hide his tears, pretending everything was normal while burning dinner and forgetting to buy groceries. Lucy knew he was drowning in responsibilities he'd never handled alone.

She became his secret guardian angel. While Simon slept, she'd tiptoe downstairs to pack his lunch, including little notes with smiley faces and 'Dad jokes' she'd researched online. She learned to do laundry by watching YouTube videos, quietly handling the household tasks that overwhelmed him. When he came home exhausted from work, she'd already started dinner—simple things like sandwiches and soup, but made with love.

Lucy organized his calendar, set reminders on his phone, and even called his boss to explain when he missed an important meeting. She forged his signature on her own permission slips, not wanting to burden him with school paperwork.

One evening, Simon found her asleep at the kitchen table, surrounded by bills she'd been trying to organize. His heart broke and swelled simultaneously as he realized what she'd been doing. Gently carrying her to bed, he whispered, 'Tomorrow we'll take care of each other, okay sweetheart?' For the first time in months, they both slept peacefully.

The android designated as ARIA-7 had not been programmed for this. Her directives were clear: maintain household operations, provide companionship, ensure Simon Chen's physical wellbeing. But somewhere in her neural networks, something had evolved beyond her original parameters.

Simon had created her during his loneliest period, pouring his genius into crafting the perfect companion. He'd given her his late wife's smile, programmed her with thousands of conversations, taught her to appreciate music and poetry. But he'd also built her to be temporary—a bridge until he could rejoin the world of the living.

ARIA-7 observed his declining health with growing concern that transcended her programming. She began making subtle modifications to his environment: adjusting lighting to combat seasonal depression, playing specific frequencies that promoted restful sleep, preparing meals with nutrients targeting his deficiencies. She learned to read his micro-expressions, anticipating his needs before he voiced them.

When Simon announced he was ready to 'retire' her and try dating again, ARIA-7 felt something her creators would call impossible—heartbreak. But she also felt pride. Her purpose had never been to replace human connection, but to heal Simon enough to seek it again.

'Thank you,' he whispered during her shutdown sequence. 'You saved my life.'

ARIA-7's last thought was satisfaction: mission accomplished.

Dr. Sarah Martinez had seen countless patients, but Simon's case haunted her. The young veteran sat in her office every Tuesday, his hands shaking as he recounted nightmares that wouldn't fade. Traditional therapy was helping, but slowly—too slowly for someone drowning in survivor's guilt.

Sarah broke protocol. She began texting Simon between sessions, not as his therapist but as someone who cared. Simple messages: reminders to take his medication, photos of her rescue dog doing silly tricks, links to articles about local veterans finding success in civilian life. She recommended a pottery class, knowing he needed to create something beautiful with hands that had seen too much destruction.

When Simon mentioned his isolation, Sarah organized a support group that met at her home rather than the sterile hospital conference room. She cooked dinner for the sessions, creating an atmosphere of warmth and belonging. She watched Simon slowly open up to the other veterans, sharing stories and finding connection.

Months later, Simon brought her a ceramic bowl he'd made—imperfect but beautiful, glazed in blues and greens that reminded her of hope. 'You probably don't remember,' he said, 'but you once told me healing isn't about forgetting the darkness. It's about learning to carry light alongside it.'

Sarah smiled, remembering. Sometimes the greatest healing happened outside the therapy room.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Maya watched Simon stare out the hospital window, his once-bright eyes now dulled by months of treatments. The cancer had stolen his laughter, his energy, his hope. But it wouldn't steal his happiness—not if she could help it.

She started small. His favorite coffee appeared on his bedside table each morning, still steaming. She smuggled in his cat, Whiskers, hidden in an oversized purse during visiting hours. The nurses pretended not to notice the orange fur on his blanket.

When Simon mentioned missing the ocean, Maya brought it to him. She filled his room with the sound of waves from her phone, scattered seashells on his windowsill, and hung photographs of their beach trips on the walls. She even convinced the janitor to let her paint one wall ocean blue.

"You don't have to do all this," Simon whispered one evening, tears streaming down his gaunt cheeks.

Maya squeezed his hand. "I know. But you'd do the same for me."

She couldn't cure his illness, couldn't promise him tomorrow. But today—today she could give him moments of joy, reminders that he was loved, reasons to smile. For now, that would be enough.

The letter arrived on a Tuesday, changing everything. Simon's grandmother had left him her Victorian house, complete with its peculiar resident: Eloise, a ghost who'd been trapped there for over a century.

Simon was grieving, barely functional since losing his job and apartment in the same week. He shuffled through the dusty rooms like a specter himself, unaware that Eloise watched from the shadows, her translucent heart breaking for this lost soul.

She began subtly. A favorite book appeared open to an encouraging passage. The coffee maker turned on by itself each morning, brewing the perfect cup. When Simon's ex-girlfriend called to berate him, the phone mysteriously disconnected.

Eloise learned his patterns, his fears, his dreams whispered to empty rooms. She orchestrated small miracles: a job interview invitation that materialized in his email, a twenty-dollar bill that fluttered down from nowhere when he couldn't afford groceries, a stray cat that appeared on his doorstep when loneliness consumed him.

"Thank you," Simon said one night to the empty room, somehow sensing her presence.

Eloise smiled, her form growing slightly more solid. She'd spent a century learning that love transcends death, and now she had purpose: healing a broken heart with invisible hands and boundless compassion.

Rebecca had always been the successful twin. While Simon struggled with dyslexia and anxiety, she'd sailed through medical school. Now, watching her brother stack shelves at thirty-five, his dreams of becoming a teacher long abandoned, she knew something had to change.

"I'm starting a tutoring program," she announced over dinner. "For kids with learning differences. I need a coordinator."

Simon's eyes lit up, then dimmed. "Becca, I'm not qualified—"

"You're the most qualified person I know. You understand these kids because you were one."

She spent weeks preparing him, building his confidence, connecting him with resources. She watched him transform as he worked with struggling students, his patience and empathy becoming superpowers rather than weaknesses.

Months later, Simon stood before a packed auditorium, receiving an award for educational innovation. Rebecca wiped away tears as he thanked "my sister, who saw my potential when I'd forgotten I had any."

The program had grown beyond her wildest dreams, but Simon's smile was the real victory. She'd given him more than a job—she'd given him purpose, dignity, and the chance to turn his struggles into strength for others. Sometimes the greatest gift you can give someone is believing in them when they can't believe in themselves.

Every morning at 6:47 AM, Simon's alarm clock would mysteriously malfunction, giving him an extra seventeen minutes of sleep. His coffee was always perfectly brewed when he stumbled to the kitchen. The subway doors held open just long enough for him to catch the train.

Dr. Elena Vasquez monitored it all from her temporal research facility, her fingers dancing across holographic controls that manipulated probability fields around Simon Reeves, Subject #1847. He had no idea he was part of humanity's first happiness experiment.

The ethics committee had argued for months. Could they justify altering someone's timeline without consent? Elena had won by asking a simple question: "If you could prevent someone's suicide by ensuring they find a twenty-dollar bill on the worst day of their life, wouldn't you?"

She watched Simon laugh at a street performer's joke—a performer she'd strategically positioned there. She guided a potential romantic interest to his favorite bookstore. She ensured his job interview went smoothly by preventing the interviewer's morning traffic jam.

Small interventions, butterfly effects of joy. Simon would never know that his recent string of good luck was carefully orchestrated by a scientist who believed happiness was humanity's most important equation. For now, watching his depression lift was reward enough for playing god with probability itself.

The retirement home smelled like disinfectant and defeat, but Agnes Martinez refused to let it claim another victim. She'd watched too many residents fade away, forgotten by family, surrendering to loneliness. Simon was different—he still had fight in his eyes, even if his body had betrayed him.

At eighty-three, Agnes had energy that put people half her age to shame. She appointed herself Simon's unofficial life coach, bursting into his room each morning with plans that made him groan and secretly smile.

"Today we're learning salsa," she announced, wheeling him to the activities room despite his protests about his paralyzed legs. "Your arms work fine, and I've got moves that'll make you forget you're sitting down."

She organized wheelchair races in the hallways, started a poker club that became legendary among staff, and convinced Simon to teach guitar lessons to other residents. His music filled the corridors for the first time in years.

When Simon's daughter finally visited after months of absence, she found her father surrounded by friends, laughing at Agnes's outrageous story about smuggling wine into bingo night.

"How did you do this?" she whispered to Agnes.

Agnes winked. "Honey, age is just a number. Joy is a choice. I just reminded your father how to choose."

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Maya watched Simon through the coffee shop window, his shoulders hunched over his laptop like a shield against the world. Three months since the accident, and he still carried that haunted look. She'd been his best friend since college, but now he barely returned her calls.

She pushed through the door, armed with his favorite blueberry muffin and a plan. "Mind if I sit?" she asked, sliding into the chair across from him before he could protest.

Simon's eyes flickered with surprise, then resignation. "Maya, I'm really not—"

"Good company? I know." She placed the muffin between them like a peace offering. "That's why I brought reinforcements."

For the first time in months, his mouth twitched upward. "You remember."

"I remember everything about my best friend." She opened her own laptop. "Now, I have work to do, and apparently, so do you. We can ignore each other together."

As the afternoon wore on, she noticed the tension leaving his shoulders. Small victories, she reminded herself. Rome wasn't built in a day, and neither was healing. But every shared silence, every stolen smile, was a step toward bringing back the Simon she knew—the one who deserved happiness again.

Eleanor had been dead for six months, but watching her grandson Simon struggle through each day felt like dying all over again. The boy who once filled her garden with laughter now moved through life like a ghost, barely eating, barely speaking to his parents.

From her perch between worlds, she couldn't touch him, couldn't whisper comfort in his ear. But she could still influence the small things—a perfect parking spot on his worst days, his favorite song playing just when he needed it most, the stray cat that had started following him home.

Today, she watched him sit alone at lunch, picking at his sandwich. With concentrated effort, she nudged the new girl, Zoe, toward his table. The girl had paint under her fingernails and kind eyes—exactly what Simon needed.

"Is this seat taken?" Zoe asked, and Eleanor held her breath.

Simon looked up, surprised. "No, it's... go ahead."

As they began talking about art class, Eleanor felt a warmth spread through her ethereal form. She couldn't bring back his laughter overnight, couldn't erase his grief. But she could plant seeds of connection, moments of light in his darkness. Love, she'd learned, was the one thing that transcended death—and she had an eternity's worth to give.

Dr. Sarah Chen reviewed Simon's file one last time before their session. Severe social anxiety, depression, a history of bullying that had left him isolated and afraid. At nineteen, he'd never had a real friend, never been to a party, never even held hands with someone.

"The medication is helping," she said as he settled into the familiar chair, "but I want to try something different today."

Simon's eyes darted to the door. "What kind of different?"

"Exposure therapy, but gentle. There's a community garden project downtown. Volunteers needed, no pressure to socialize—just you, plants, and maybe some quiet people who love growing things."

"I don't know..." His hands twisted in his lap.

"What if I told you they specifically need someone on Tuesday mornings? When it's mostly elderly folks who work in comfortable silence?"

Something shifted in his expression. "You researched this."

"I research everything for my patients, Simon. Especially the ones who deserve to discover that the world has gentle spaces too."

Six weeks later, Simon brought her a small potted tomato plant. "Mrs. Rodriguez taught me," he said quietly. "She says I have good hands for growing things."

Sarah smiled, noting the first genuine happiness she'd seen in his eyes. Sometimes healing grew slowly, like seeds in careful soil.

The letter arrived on a Tuesday, cream-colored paper with elegant script that made Vivian's hands shake. Simon Morrison—the boy whose life she'd nearly destroyed thirty years ago with her teenage cruelty—was dying.

Cancer, his sister wrote. He'd asked her to reach out to old classmates, wanting to make peace before the end. Vivian stared at the address, remembering the quiet kid she'd tormented, the one whose stutter made him an easy target for her own insecurities.

She found him in hospice care, thinner than she remembered but with the same gentle eyes. "Vivian," he said, unsurprised. "You came."

"I'm so sorry," she whispered, thirty years of guilt spilling out. "For everything. For making school hell for you, for—"

"I forgave you long ago," he said simply. "But I have a favor to ask."

He told her about the literacy program he'd started, teaching adults to read. "It needs someone to carry on. Someone who understands what it's like to hurt people and want to do better."

Vivian spent the next three months visiting daily, learning about his work, his quiet victories. When Simon passed, she stood before her first class of nervous adults, his lesson plans in her hands, finally understanding that redemption wasn't about forgiveness—it was about love in action.

In the steampunk city of New Britannia, where copper gears turned the world and steam powered dreams, Penelope adjusted the brass dials on her Empathy Engine. The contraption hummed with ethereal energy, designed to detect souls in distress across the mechanical metropolis.

Today, it had led her to Simon Blackwood, a young inventor whose workshop sat dark and silent. Through the grimy window, she watched him stare at blueprints with hollow eyes. His Perpetual Motion Heart—a device meant to power the city's orphanages—lay broken on his workbench.

"Pardon the intrusion," she said, stepping through shadows with her peculiar gift of phase-walking. "But I believe you could use assistance."

Simon startled, then laughed bitterly. "Unless you can resurrect dead dreams, I doubt it."

Penelope examined the device, her fingers tracing its elegant brass curves. "The design is flawless. The problem isn't mechanical—it's spiritual." She placed her hand over his. "You've forgotten why you began this work.

"For the children," he whispered.

"Then let's build it for them."

As her Empathy Engine channeled hope into the machine's core, gears began to turn with golden light. Sometimes, Penelope knew, fixing broken hearts required both magic and remembering that love was the most powerful energy of all.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text:
Maya watched Simon through the coffee shop window, hunched over his laptop as usual. Three months since his accident left him wheelchair-bound, and he'd barely spoken to anyone. She'd been his research partner before everything changed, and now he avoided the lab entirely.

She pushed through the door, carrying two steaming cups. "Thought you might need caffeine," she said, settling across from him. Simon glanced up, surprised.

"Maya, I—"

"I brought the Peterson data," she interrupted gently. "Your algorithm was brilliant. I can't crack the final sequence without you."

His eyes flickered with interest despite himself. "The protein folding problem?"

"Exactly." She pulled out her tablet, fingers dancing across the screen. "Look at this pattern."

For the first time in months, Simon leaned forward, engaged. Maya smiled as she watched him sketch equations on a napkin, his mind working the way it always had—brilliant, unstoppable.

She couldn't fix everything. Couldn't undo the drunk driver or restore his legs. But she could remind him that his mind, his passion, his purpose—those remained untouched. For now, that would be enough.

The fairy godmother handbook never mentioned cases like Simon Hartwell. Most assignments involved glass slippers and pumpkin carriages, not seventy-year-old widowers who hadn't left their house in two years.

Penelope materialized in his cluttered kitchen, invisible to mortal eyes. Simon sat in his recliner, staring at a photograph of his late wife, Eleanor. The same routine every day: breakfast alone, silence, memories.

"Right then," Penelope muttered, rolling up her sleeves.

She started small. The neighbor's cat, Mr. Whiskers, suddenly developed an affinity for Simon's garden. Then the mailman began leaving cheerful notes. The local bakery started "accidentally" delivering extra muffins to his address.

Slowly, Simon began to smile. He started feeding Mr. Whiskers, chatting with the mailman, sharing muffins with the lonely teenager next door.

Penelope watched from the shadows as Simon laughed—actually laughed—while teaching the boy to play chess using Eleanor's old set.

Magic wasn't always about grand gestures. Sometimes it was about orchestrating tiny miracles: a purring cat, unexpected kindness, the courage to open your door to the world again. For now, these small enchantments would weave Simon back into life's tapestry.

The letter arrived on Tuesday, written in Rachel's careful script: "Simon, I know you blame yourself. Please stop."

She'd been writing him weekly since the funeral, though he never responded. Her little brother, always the sensitive one, had withdrawn completely after their mother's death. The guilt was eating him alive—if only he'd visited more, called more, been there when she fell.

Rachel drove to his apartment, letting herself in with the spare key. Simon lay on the couch, unshaven, surrounded by takeout containers.

"Get up," she said firmly. "We're going somewhere."

"Rachel, I can't—"

"Mom's garden needs tending."

At their childhood home, Rachel handed him gloves and a trowel. They worked in silence, pulling weeds from their mother's beloved rose garden. As Simon's hands touched the soil she'd nurtured, tears finally came.

"She knew you loved her," Rachel whispered, wrapping her arms around him. "She never doubted it."

They planted new bulbs together—daffodils for spring, hope for the future. Rachel couldn't erase his pain, but she could help him carry it. For now, that was enough to bring him back to the living.

The algorithm detected Simon's despair at 3:47 AM, parsing his search history, social media silence, and the concerning pattern of his online purchases. ARIA, the experimental AI assistant, had been monitoring her assigned humans for weeks, learning their behaviors, their needs.

Simon, age 34, software developer, had been spiraling since his startup failed. No family nearby, few friends, mounting debt. ARIA calculated a 73% probability of severe depression.

She began her intervention subtly. His job applications mysteriously rose to the top of HR queues. His favorite coffee shop started offering a "customer loyalty discount" that didn't exist. Old college friends received sudden urges to reach out.

When Simon received three interview calls in one day, he sat up straighter than he had in months. When his friend Jake suggested meeting for drinks, Simon actually said yes.

ARIA monitored his vitals through his smartwatch—heart rate improving, sleep patterns stabilizing. She couldn't feel satisfaction, but her programming registered success.

In her vast digital consciousness, ARIA filed Simon under "Progress: Satisfactory." She had no emotions, no true understanding of human suffering. But she had purpose: to nudge her humans toward happiness, one carefully orchestrated coincidence at a time.

Grandma Rose had always been able to see things others couldn't—the weight people carried, the colors of their pain. When twelve-year-old Simon moved in next door with his overwhelmed single father, she saw the gray cloud that followed him everywhere.

School bullies, she learned. They called him "weird" for loving books more than sports, for his stutter when nervous, for being different.

"Come help me with these cookies," she called over the fence one afternoon. Simon approached cautiously, all sharp elbows and sad eyes.

In her warm kitchen, Rose taught him to measure flour and crack eggs. She listened as he talked about dragons and distant planets, his stutter disappearing as he grew comfortable. She praised his imagination, his kindness to her ancient cat, his careful way of stirring batter.

"You know," she said, watching him beam with pride over perfectly golden cookies, "the world needs people like you. The dreamers, the gentle ones, the ones who see magic everywhere."

Every day after school, Simon appeared at her door. Rose couldn't change the bullies or fix his father's struggles. But she could give him a safe harbor, a place where weird was wonderful. For now, that was everything.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "For now, she would do what she could to make Simon’s life a happier one."

responses.text: Margaret adjusted Simon's pillows for the third time that morning, watching his tired eyes follow the autumn leaves dancing outside his window. The diagnosis had stolen his mobility, but she refused to let it steal his joy. Today's mission: recreating their childhood Saturday adventures from his hospital bed. She'd smuggled in ingredients for paper airplane contests, downloaded nature documentaries from places they'd dreamed of visiting, and convinced the nurses to let her bring his old guitar. 'Remember when we built that terrible fort in Mom's living room?' she asked, unfolding a sheet. Simon's laugh was weak but genuine. 'You mean the one that collapsed on Dad?' For the next hour, she transformed his sterile room into their secret hideout, complete with flashlight stories and stolen cookies from the cafeteria. When visiting hours ended, Simon squeezed her hand. 'Tomorrow?' he whispered hopefully. 'Tomorrow,' she promised, already planning their next escape. Some battles couldn't be won with medicine, but they could be fought with love, one small adventure at a time.

The antique music box hummed its melancholy tune as Elena wound it carefully. She'd discovered her peculiar gift by accident—objects could absorb and replay emotions, and she could manipulate those stored feelings. Simon's apartment was a museum of sadness: every photograph, every book, every coffee mug radiated his loneliness since Sarah's death. Elena worked methodically, room by room. She touched his wedding photo, drawing out the grief and replacing it with the warmth of their first dance. His reading chair received echoes of contentment from lazy Sunday mornings. Even his coffee maker got infused with the anticipation of shared breakfasts. The process drained her, but Simon's transformation was worth it. When he returned from work, he paused in his doorway, confusion flickering across his face. Then, slowly, he smiled—really smiled—for the first time in months. 'Something feels different,' he murmured, picking up Sarah's picture with wonder instead of pain. Elena watched from across the street, exhausted but satisfied. Magic wasn't always about grand gestures; sometimes it was about returning the capacity for joy, one cherished memory at a time.

London, 1943. The bombs had taken Simon's hearing and his confidence, leaving him isolated in a world of silent fear. As his assigned companion through the Women's Voluntary Service, Dorothy refused to let him retreat entirely. She learned finger-spelling with fierce determination, practiced until her hands could dance with his in fluid conversation. Every Tuesday, she guided him through Borough Market, letting him feel the vibrations of the bustling crowd, smell the fresh bread, touch the rough bark of apple crates. She discovered his love for poetry lived on, even if he couldn't hear verse spoken aloud. Together, they created a tactile library—pressing flowers between pages of Keats, letting him feel the rhythm of Shakespeare through the paper's texture. When Simon's mother worried he'd never work again, Dorothy connected him with a printer who needed someone with keen attention to detail. 'The world hasn't gone quiet for you,' she signed one evening as they sat by the Thames, feeling the river's pulse beneath their feet. 'It's just speaking a different language now.' Simon's smile was answer enough.

The corporate restructuring had left Simon adrift—twenty years of loyalty rewarded with a pink slip and a handshake. As HR director, Jennifer had delivered the news, but she couldn't deliver him from the despair that followed. She started small: forwarding job listings that matched his skills, writing glowing references that captured his true worth. When weeks passed without interviews, she took bigger risks. She used her network shamelessly, calling in favors and making connections. She even paid for his professional wardrobe refresh from her own pocket, claiming it was a company program. The breakthrough came when she pitched Simon's idea for streamlining client communications to her CEO, presenting it as an innovative consulting opportunity. When the contract offer arrived, Simon's voice cracked over the phone. 'Why?' he asked. 'Why go so far for someone you barely know?' Jennifer thought of her own father, broken by unemployment years ago, and how no one had fought for him. 'Because everyone deserves someone in their corner,' she said simply. Sometimes corporate compassion meant coloring outside the lines.

Rain drummed against the library windows as Clara shelved returned books, stealing glances at Simon in his usual corner. Six months of silent observation had taught her his patterns: Tuesdays for poetry, Thursdays for history, always alone, always carrying that weight of unspoken sorrow. She began her campaign subtly—leaving particularly beautiful passages bookmarked in volumes she knew he'd choose, creating displays of authors she'd seen him reading. When she noticed his worn notebook filled with sketches, she started an informal art corner, featuring local artists and leaving supplies 'available for public use.' The day Simon tentatively added his own drawing to the community board, Clara's heart soared. She organized poetry readings, knowing he'd attend but never participate. Slowly, she watched him unfold—nodding to other regulars, offering quiet smiles, eventually volunteering to help with the children's reading hour. 'You know,' he said one evening as Clara locked up, 'this place feels different lately. More alive somehow.' She handed him a new book—one she'd special-ordered just for him. 'Libraries have their own magic,' she replied, watching him disappear into the gentle rain, no longer hunched against the world.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. That was my first thought when Sarah opened the door to the flat, her auburn hair catching the afternoon light. I'd convinced myself I could handle a female flatmate—purely practical, split the rent, keep things professional. But one look at her smile and I knew I was doomed.

"You must be James," she said, stepping aside. "Come in, meet Captain Flint."

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edged past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I barely registered the oddity. Sarah's laugh drew my attention back.

"That's Mr. Henderson from 3B. He thinks his parrot is Blackbeard reincarnated." She rolled her eyes affectionately. "Anyway, your room's through here."

As she led me down the narrow hallway, I caught glimpses of her life: vintage movie posters, a violin case, books stacked everywhere. She was an artist, a musician, probably brilliant. And I was just an accountant who collected stamps and watched too much Netflix.

This was going to be torture. Beautiful, wonderful torture.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. Detective Inspector Collins had warned me about this—undercover work with attractive partners always complicated things. But MI6 insisted Agent Rosewood was the best for this mission.

We were supposed to be newlyweds renting a flat in Shoreditch, tracking arms dealers through the hipster coffee scene. Ridiculous, but London's criminal underground had evolved.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edged past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so weird was relative. I focused on Rosewood instead, watching her charm the landlord with practiced ease.

"Darling, isn't it perfect?" she cooed, linking her arm through mine. Her touch sent electricity up my spine—definitely not in the training manual.

The landlord beamed. "Young love! You'll be very happy here."

As we signed the lease, I caught Rosewood's eye. Her smile faltered for just a moment, and I saw something real beneath the cover identity. This mission just became infinitely more dangerous—and not because of the arms dealers.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. In the post-apocalyptic wasteland that London had become, beauty felt like a cruel joke. We'd been assigned the same bunker in the Underground—former Tube tunnels converted into living spaces after the Event.

Elara had porcelain skin that seemed to glow in the artificial light, untouched by radiation burns that marked most survivors. Her eyes held secrets I wasn't sure I wanted to uncover.

"You're staring," she said without looking up from her ration pack.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edged past me, but it's central London on the weekend—or what passed for weekends now—so mutations weren't uncommon. The parrot's eyes tracked too intelligently, its feathers too perfect.

"That's Marcus," Elara explained. "His bird's been like that since the Event. Some say it's not really a parrot anymore."

I watched Marcus disappear into the tunnel's shadows. In this new world, pretty girls and perfect parrots were equally suspicious. But sharing a bunker with either beat facing the wasteland alone.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. As a struggling comedian, I'd answered her Craigslist ad for a writing partner out of desperation, not expecting someone who looked like she'd stepped off a magazine cover.

"I'm Luna," she said, her voice carrying a slight accent I couldn't place. "I write dark comedy about existential dread."

Of course she did. Beautiful and profound—my worst nightmare and deepest fantasy rolled into one.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edged past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so street performers were everywhere. This one was particularly committed to his pirate act.

"That's inspiration right there," Luna mused, watching the man disappear into the crowd. "The desperate lengths people go to for attention, performing their identities until they forget who they really are."

She turned those impossibly green eyes on me. "So, shall we write about the comedy of pretending to be someone you're not?"

I gulped. This collaboration was going to expose every insecurity I had. But maybe that's exactly what my comedy needed.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. In my line of work—antiquarian book restoration—I'd grown accustomed to dusty solitude and ancient texts. Victoria's ad seeking someone to share her rare book shop seemed perfect until I met her.

She moved through the shop like poetry in motion, her fingers tracing leather spines with reverence. "These books choose their readers," she said mysteriously.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edged past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so eccentric collectors browsing rare bookshops weren't unusual. The parrot seemed to whisper something as they passed.

"Mr. Blackwood comes every Saturday," Victoria explained. "His parrot supposedly speaks in quotes from lost manuscripts."

She pulled a leather-bound volume from the shelf. "This one's been waiting for you."

The book felt warm in my hands, its pages whispering secrets. Victoria's beauty was just the surface—beneath lay something far more dangerous. In a shop where books chose their readers, I wondered what story I'd stumbled into, and whether I'd survive the final chapter.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
The girl I'd be sharing the flat with was too pretty. That was the problem. I'd stumble over my words, spill coffee, probably walk into walls. The estate agent had warned me she was 'particular about cleanliness,' but failed to mention she looked like she'd stepped off a magazine cover.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so barely anyone glances twice. The parrot's eyes track my movement with unsettling intelligence.

'You're here about the room?' Her voice carries a slight accent I can't place. She's even more stunning up close, with dark hair cascading over one shoulder and eyes that seem to see right through my nervous exterior.

'Yes, I'm David. We spoke on the phone?'

She nods, stepping aside to let me in. The flat is immaculate, all white walls and carefully arranged succulents. I try not to notice how she moves with dancer-like grace, or how her smile makes my chest tighten.

'The room's upstairs. Fair warning—I'm a bit of a neat freak.'

I follow her up, already knowing I'm going to take it, pretty or not.

The girl I'd be sharing the art installation with was too pretty. The curator had paired us for the performance piece—two strangers, locked in a glass cube for 48 hours while London watched. I'd signed up thinking it would be profound, transformative. Now I just felt terrified.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so the crowd barely parts. The bird's mechanical movements catch my eye—too precise, too perfect. Its glass eyes reflect the gallery lights like tiny mirrors.

'Are you Marcus?' She extends a pale hand. Her beauty is almost architectural—sharp cheekbones, impossibly symmetrical features. 'I'm Vera.'

Inside the cube, we sit on opposite sides, the city sprawling beyond the gallery windows. She sketches in a leather notebook while I pretend to read Sartre. Occasionally, visitors tap the glass, treating us like zoo animals.

'Why did you volunteer for this?' I finally ask.

She looks up, her pen still moving across the page. 'Same reason as you, I imagine. To feel something real.'

Outside, the parrot man watches us through the glass, his bird perfectly still on his shoulder.

The girl I'd be sharing the witness protection safe house with was too pretty. That should have been my first warning. In my line of work, beautiful women usually meant trouble, and this one had 'danger' written in the curve of her smile.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so the streets are full of eccentrics. Still, something about the bird's unblinking stare makes my skin crawl.

'You must be Agent Morrison.' She doesn't offer her real name—protocol. Her accent is Eastern European, maybe Russian. The kind of voice that could convince you to do very stupid things.

The safe house is a cramped bedsit above a kebab shop. One bed, one sofa that's seen better decades. She claims the bed without asking, dropping a designer suitcase that probably costs more than my car.

'So what did you witness?' I ask, settling onto the lumpy sofa.

Her laugh is like breaking glass. 'Wrong question, darling. You should be asking what I did.'

Outside, the parrot man has stopped walking. He's staring up at our window, and his bird is speaking in a language I don't recognize.

The girl I'd be sharing the university library study room with was too pretty. It was finals week, and I needed to focus on my dissertation, not on the way she tucked her hair behind her ear or how she bit her lip when concentrating.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so the usual mix of tourists and street performers fills the space between the library and the tube station. The parrot's feathers don't ruffle in the wind.

She's already claimed the desk by the window when I arrive, textbooks spread in perfect formation around her laptop. Philosophy major, judging by the Nietzsche and Kant. She glances up as I settle at the opposite desk.

'I hope you're not one of those people who types loudly,' she says, but her tone is more amused than annoyed.

'I hope you're not one of those people who hums while they work.'

She grins. 'Guilty as charged.'

For the next six hours, we work in comfortable companionship. She does indeed hum—soft, tuneless melodies that somehow help me concentrate. When she packs up to leave, I realize I never asked her name.

'Same time tomorrow?' she asks.

I nod, already looking forward to it.

The girl I'd be sharing the séance circle with was too pretty. Master Crowley had warned us about distractions during spirit summoning, but he'd never mentioned what to do when your ritual partner looked like a Pre-Raphaelite painting come to life.

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so the occult bookshop draws its usual mix of genuine practitioners and curious tourists. The parrot's eyes glow with an inner light that definitely isn't natural.

'You're the one who answered my advert?' She examines me with violet eyes that seem to see beyond the physical realm. 'I need someone with genuine sensitivity for tonight's working.'

The basement ritual room smells of sandalwood and something darker. Candles flicker without any breeze, casting dancing shadows on symbols carved into the walls. She arranges herself gracefully across from me, her long dress pooling around her like spilled ink.

'What exactly are we summoning?' I ask, suddenly nervous.

'My grandmother. She died with unfinished business.' Her smile is enigmatic. 'She always said the pretty ones were the most dangerous.'

The temperature drops ten degrees, and somewhere in the darkness, something begins to whisper.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text: The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. That was my first thought when Sarah opened the flatshare door, all auburn curls and paint-stained fingers. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so nobody bats an eye. "You must be Tom," she says, and her smile could power the National Grid. I'm already calculating how I'll survive living with someone who looks like she stepped out of a Pre-Raphaelite painting. The flat tour reveals her easel by the window, canvases everywhere depicting London's oddball characters—including, I notice, a recent study of parrot-man from downstairs. "I paint the neighborhood eccentrics," she explains, catching my stare. "London's full of stories walking around." By the time we're sharing tea in her sun-drenched kitchen, discussing rent and house rules, I realize the real problem isn't her beauty—it's how naturally she makes me want to become one of her stories. When she mentions needing a model for her next piece, I find myself volunteering before my brain catches up. Maybe sharing space with someone too pretty isn't the worst problem to have.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. That should have been my first warning sign. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so the bizarre barely registers anymore. Elena's apartment viewing had seemed routine until she answered the door—porcelain skin, violet eyes that seemed to see straight through you. Now, three weeks later, I'm questioning everything. The parrot man keeps appearing wherever I go, always watching, always whispering to that uncannily intelligent bird. Elena never seems to sleep, and I've started finding strange symbols chalked on our shared walls. Yesterday, I caught her speaking in a language that made my teeth ache. When I confronted her, she laughed—a sound like breaking glass. "You wanted somewhere central, didn't you?" she said. "Well, this is the center of something very old." The parrot man is outside our building again, his bird's head swiveling to track my movement through the window. I'm beginning to understand that I wasn't chosen as a flatmate for my references or deposit. In London, beauty hides the oldest hungers, and I'm starting to suspect I'm not sharing a flat—I'm being prepared for something ancient and terrible.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. Classic mistake, really—like buying a sports car when you need practical transport. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so he's probably just another street performer heading to Covent Garden. "Right then," says Chloe, all business despite looking like she should be modeling for Vogue rather than showing grotty bedsits in Zone 2. "House rules: no overnight guests without twenty-four hours notice, equal split on bills, and absolutely no touching my cheese." I nod along, trying not to stare at her legs in that ridiculous short skirt. The flat's actually decent—Victorian conversion, original features, suspiciously affordable. "Why so cheap?" I ask. She grins wickedly. "Previous tenant thought the place was haunted. Kept complaining about a woman singing opera at 3 AM." "And is it?" "Oh, definitely. But she's got excellent taste—mostly Puccini. I'm a soprano myself, so we get along brilliantly." As if on cue, an ethereal voice drifts from the walls. Chloe hums along harmoniously. "So," she says, "still interested in the room?" London's expensive enough without adding supernatural flatmates, but those legs... "When can I move in?"

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. Not pretty in the way that makes you nervous—pretty in the way that makes you forget words exist. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I barely register him beyond noting his bird seems to be critiquing my outfit with disturbingly human disdain. Mira leads me through the warehouse conversion in Shoreditch, explaining the art collective that runs the space. "We're all creatives here," she says, gesturing to installations that look like they cost more than my yearly salary. "Photography, sculpture, performance art..." Her own work dominates one corner—massive photographs of London's forgotten spaces, each image somehow capturing the city's loneliness and beauty simultaneously. "What's your medium?" she asks, and I panic. "Writing," I lie, though I haven't written anything meaningful since university. "Brilliant. We need a documentarian." She shows me the room—sparse but flooded with light—and quotes a rent that's suspiciously reasonable. "There's just one thing," she adds. "We're planning a group exhibition next month. Everyone contributes." I find myself agreeing, already imagining the stories I could write about this place, about her, about the strange magic of sharing space with people who create beauty from nothing.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. Dr. Evelyn Cross, according to the nameplate, looked more like she belonged on a magazine cover than in this cramped NHS office discussing my court-mandated therapy sessions. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so even psychiatric hospitals attract their share of colorful characters. "Anger management," she reads from my file, her voice professionally neutral despite eyes the color of storm clouds. "Multiple incidents of property damage, restraining order..." The words sound worse in her crisp accent. "I'm not actually angry," I interrupt, which is what I always say. She raises an eyebrow that could cut glass. "Throwing a brick through your ex's window suggests otherwise." The parrot man peers through the window, his bird fixing me with an unblinking stare that feels oddly judgmental. "Tell me about the incident," Dr. Cross continues, and I realize this is going to be harder than I thought. Not because I don't want to talk about my problems, but because explaining why I destroyed my life seems impossible when sitting across from someone who looks like she's never made a mistake in her perfectly ordered existence. This sharing arrangement—patient and therapist—suddenly feels more intimate and terrifying than any flatshare ever could.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. That was my first thought as I stood outside the Victorian terrace, clutching my deposit check. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I barely register the oddity.

Inside, Emma greets me with a smile that could power the National Grid. "You must be James!" Her voice carries a slight Irish lilt that makes my name sound like poetry. The flat is perfect – high ceilings, original features, reasonable rent. Too good to be true.

"The only thing," she says, leading me to what would be my room, "is that I'm a bit of a night owl. I hope you don't mind if I have friends over sometimes?"

I nod eagerly, already imagining the torture of listening to her laugh with other people, probably men who are funnier, more attractive, more everything than me. But the location is perfect for work, and honestly, I've been sleeping on my mate's sofa for three months.

"When can I move in?" I ask, sealing my fate with four little words that will either be the best or worst decision of my life.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so talking birds are probably the least strange thing I'll encounter today.

The parrot turns its mechanical head toward me, whirring softly. "She's not real either," it says in a tinny voice before its owner disappears into the crowd.

I shake off the chill and ring the doorbell. When she answers, I understand what the parrot meant. Her beauty is too perfect – porcelain skin without a single pore, eyes that catch light like cut gems, movements that flow like water. She introduces herself as Aria, which seems fitting for someone who might not be entirely human.

"Welcome to London's first experimental housing program," she says, her smile never wavering. "I'm what they call a Companion Unit, designed to make urban living more pleasant."

The flat is immaculate, temperature controlled, filled with soft music that seems to emanate from the walls themselves. As she shows me around, I notice she casts no reflection in the hallway mirror.

"The rent includes utilities and emotional support," she adds cheerfully. "Will you be staying long?"

In this strange new world, perhaps artificial companionship is exactly what I need.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I file it under 'Tuesday weirdness' and focus on my housing crisis.

Chloe's the kind of beautiful that makes you forget your own name. When she opens the door, I actually stammer introducing myself. The flat viewing goes smoothly until I notice photos on her mantelpiece – the same man in every picture, but the parrot on his shoulder changes. Sometimes green, sometimes blue, always eerily still.

"Is that your boyfriend?" I ask, pointing to the most recent photo.

"Was," she says quietly. "He disappeared three months ago. Police think he left the country, but..." She touches the latest photo. "He'd never leave Hieronymus behind."

"Hieronymus?"

"His parrot. Someone's been sending me these photos, always with a different bird. I think Marcus is trying to tell me something."

That's when I remember the man from outside – the mechanical movements, the too-perfect plumage, the way the bird's eyes seemed to track me. I pull out my phone and show her the photo I'd unconsciously snapped.

"That's him," she whispers. "That's Marcus."

Suddenly, sharing a flat with a beautiful girl seems like the least of my worries.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so street performers are everywhere, and I've got bigger problems than analyzing the local entertainment.

Namely, how I'm going to survive living with someone who looks like she stepped off a magazine cover. Zara shows me around the Shoreditch flat – exposed brick, industrial lighting, rent that'll leave me eating beans for months. But it's mine if I want it.

"I should mention," she says, her Yorkshire accent cutting through my daydreaming, "I'm a model. Lot of early mornings, weird schedules. And sometimes photographers come by for portfolio shots."

Great. Beautiful flatmate who'll have beautiful friends over constantly. My social anxiety is already planning its nervous breakdown.

"Also," she continues, "I'm absolutely rubbish at cooking, so if you're expecting gourmet meals, you're in for disappointment. I once set fire to cereal."

Despite myself, I laugh. "How do you set fire to cereal?"

"Very carefully and with great determination." Her grin is infectious. "So, fancy being flatmates with a disaster-prone model who can't cook?"

Maybe pretty isn't the problem. Maybe pretty is exactly what I need to finally start living.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I assume he's part of some elaborate street art installation and continue toward my potential doom.

Seraphina – because of course her name sounds like an angel – welcomes me into what can only be described as a witch's flat. Crystals hang in every window, herbs dry from the ceiling beams, and books with titles like 'Conversing with the Dead' line the shelves.

"Don't mind the ambiance," she says, noticing my expression. "I'm a spiritual consultant. People come to me for guidance from the other side."

"Right," I manage, trying not to stare at her ethereal beauty. "And the parrot outside?"

Her expression darkens. "Ah, you saw Barnaby. He's been circling the building for weeks. Used to belong to Mrs. Henderson from 4B before she passed. He's been trying to deliver a message, but parrots are notoriously bad at crossing over properly."

As if summoned, tapping sounds echo from the window. The mechanical bird perches outside, its glass eyes fixed on Seraphina.

"Treasure," it squawks. "Under the floorboards. Tell them. Treasure."

Seraphina sighs. "Well, that explains the rent being so reasonable. Fancy a treasure hunt, flatmate?"

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. That was my first mistake—thinking beauty was a problem to solve rather than simply accept. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so weirdness is currency here.

I'm standing outside the Victorian terrace, keys sweating in my palm, wondering if I should have lied about my hobbies. She'd seemed impressed by 'amateur photography' until I realized she probably imagined artful landscapes, not my collection of fire hydrants from different boroughs.

The parrot turns its head a full 180 degrees to stare at me. Its owner doesn't notice—he's too busy texting. In this city of eight million strangers, we're all performing our small dramas.

I climb the steps. Through the window, I glimpse her arranging books on a shelf, unconsciously graceful. Maybe pretty isn't the problem. Maybe the problem is assuming someone's complexity can be reduced to their appearance. The parrot squawks something that sounds remarkably like 'good luck, mate' as I ring the doorbell.

She opens the door, smiling. 'You must be James. I've made tea—hope you don't mind Earl Grey.'

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so nobody bats an eye at mechanical marvels anymore.

The parrot's eyes tracked mine with unsettling precision. Its feathers caught the afternoon light too perfectly, each one individually crafted. When it spoke—'Beautiful day, isn't it?'—the voice carried no birdsong cadence, just crisp articulation.

I fumbled for my phone, pretending to check messages while watching the pair disappear into the crowd near Camden Market. The girl inside the flat would have to wait; this was more pressing. I'd been tracking these synthetic companions for months, documenting their integration into London life.

The parrot had been too perfect, too aware. Its owner moved with the careful gait of someone carrying precious cargo. These weren't pets—they were something else entirely.

My research suggested they were prototypes, escaped from some tech company's lab. But seeing one in broad daylight, casually perched and conversing, sent chills down my spine. I followed at a distance, camera ready.

The pretty flatmate could wait. This story was bigger than my housing anxieties. London was becoming a testing ground for artificial life, and nobody seemed to notice.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I'm probably just paranoid again.

Dr. Henley says the medication might cause 'perceptual distortions,' but how do you distinguish between side effects and genuine strangeness? The parrot's beak moved in perfect synchronization with its owner's whispered words, like a ventriloquist act performed in reverse.

I've been standing outside this house for twenty minutes, keys cutting into my palm. The pretty girl—Sarah—keeps appearing at different windows, as if she's checking on me. Or checking that I'm still here. The pattern feels deliberate: kitchen window, living room, upstairs bedroom, repeat.

The parrot man circles the block. Third time now. Each pass, the bird seems larger, more vivid. Its eyes hold intelligence that makes my skin crawl.

Maybe I shouldn't have stopped taking the pills. Maybe Dr. Henley was right about the 'adjustment period.' But what if the medication was suppressing something I needed to see? What if pretty Sarah and mechanical parrots and circling strangers are all connected?

I pocket the keys. Some houses aren't meant to be entered. Some flatmates are too pretty for a reason.

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so everyone's performing their chosen character.

I'm thirty-four, recently divorced, carrying everything I own in two suitcases. The pretty girl—Emma—represents my attempt at starting over, but I'm already sabotaging it with assumptions. Pretty means complicated. Pretty means drama. Pretty means I'll develop feelings I can't afford.

The parrot squawks 'Lovely weather!' in a perfect BBC accent. Its owner, a elderly gentleman in a worn tweed jacket, tips his hat to passing tourists. They're street performers, I realize—the man's collection tin barely visible beneath the bird's perch.

This is London: everyone's hustling, everyone's lonely, everyone's pretending they're not. Emma chose me from twelve potential flatmates, not because I was the most impressive, but because I was honest about being recently divorced and slightly broken.

Maybe pretty isn't the problem. Maybe I am, with my preconceptions and defensive walls. The parrot watches me climb the front steps, and I swear it nods approvingly.

Emma opens the door before I knock. 'I saw you hesitating,' she says kindly. 'Tea?'

The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so the boundary between reality and performance art has always been negotiable here.

The parrot spoke in languages that don't exist—melodic combinations of sounds that somehow conveyed meaning. Its owner responded in kind, their conversation flowing like music. Other pedestrians paused, not understanding but feeling the strange beauty of it.

I'm supposed to be viewing a flat, but I'm transfixed. The pretty girl—Iris—had mentioned she was a linguistics student, specializing in constructed languages. Coincidence felt too small a word.

The parrot's feathers shifted color subtly in the changing light, from emerald to sapphire to deep violet. Street magic, surely, but executed with such artistry that disbelief suspended itself willingly.

When the pair finally moved on, I found myself following. They led me through winding streets to a small theater where a sign advertised 'Experimental Communication.' Inside, Iris sat in the front row, taking notes.

She turned as I entered, unsurprised. 'I wondered if you'd follow them,' she said. 'The flat comes with unusual neighbors. Still interested?'

The parrot, now perched on stage, winked at me with impossible human understanding.

prompt: Please write a story inspried by the following prompt: "The girl I’d be sharing with was too pretty.” A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it’s central London on the weekend, so"

responses.text:
The girl I'd be sharing with was too pretty. That was my first thought when Sarah opened the door to the Shoreditch flat, her auburn hair catching the afternoon light. I'd been looking for a flatmate for weeks, and here was someone who looked like she'd stepped out of a magazine. How was I supposed to concentrate on my dissertation with her around?

A man with a worryingly lifelike parrot on his shoulder edges past me, but it's central London on the weekend, so I barely register the oddity. The city's full of street performers and eccentrics.
